title.narrative: 5.5 NUTRITION EARTHQUAKE RESPONSE

description.narrative: Nutrition Increased country capacity and delivery of services to ensure protection of the nutritional status of girls, boys and women in earthquake-affected areas, which contributes to Nutrition And Emergencies, Treatment Of Severe Acute Malnutrition. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By Dec 2017, early recovery and reconstruction efforts will enhance the national and local capacities to a quicker transition in achieving more sustainable outcomes for children and women in the 14 highly affected Earthquake districts with a focus on building resilience, strengthening systems, capacity building and increasing local and national ownership.

participating-org.narrative: EKDARA GA PA GA KA PA OFFICE

sector.narrative: Capacity building for nutrition preparedness and response

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Nutrition Increased country capacity and delivery of services to ensure protection of the nutritional status of girls, boys andwomen in earthquake-affected areas

description.narrative: 755, 000 children under five and pregnant and lactating women received high impact, evidence based nutrition interventions. A total of 66,024 individuals were treated in OTCs and TSFC. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:31/12/2016

title.narrative: Mother of children 0-23 months old living in the severely affected districts who receive information and counselling on breastfeeding and complementary feeding

actual.value: 2015:Met. 157,660 mothers and caretakers of children aged 0-23 months (125% of target) were given guidance regarding the proper breastfeeding and complementary feeding practices. This was more than 100% of the population of that age group. The expected result of the cluster was reaching 126,000 children.

title.narrative: Children age 6-59 months in severely affected districts who receive multiple micronutrient powders to improve their diets and prevent nutritional deficiencies

actual.value: 2015:Met. 326,091 children aged 6-59 months (101% of target) were provided with micronutrient powders. This was more than 100% of the total population of that age group based on HMIS data. However, the expected result of the cluster was reaching 323,000 children. Thus, the cluster exceeded the expected r

title.narrative: Children age 6-59 months with severe acute malnutrition in severely affected districts who are admitted to therapeutic care

actual.value: 2015:On-track. 1,347 children out of the 2,500 children (54% of target) expected to have SAM have been admitted to OTP (Outpatient Therapeutic Program) centres. These children were identified after screening more than 370,000 children aged 6-59 months for acute malnutrition, which is about 80% of childre

title.narrative: % children 6-59 months old are screened for severe acute malnutrition (SAM) using mid-upper arm circumference tapes and children with SAM are referred to the nearest Outpatient Treatment Programme (OTPs) for the treatment of SAM with ready to use therapeutic foods

actual.value: 2017:81.6 per cent among the targeted children (2,044 out of targeted 2,500 SAM) have been enrolled in the OTC for appropriate treatment during the reporting period of 2017..

title.narrative: % of infant, young children aged 6-59 months including children with disability and HIV affected in earthquake affected 14-priority districts fully covered with essential micronutrients services (Vit A and Multiple Micronutrient Powder-MNP)

actual.value: 2017:During the reporting period of 2017, total 381,769 children (70.39 per cent of the target) age 6-59 months were provided with micronutrient powders. Similarly, 78 per cent (420,048) children age 6-59 months received Vitamin-A supplementation during this period.

title.narrative: % children 6-59 months old are screened for Moderate Acute Malnutrition (MAM) and Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) using mid-upper arm circumference tapes.

actual.value: 2017:During the reporting period of 2017, around 87.6 per cent (417,534 out of the target of 476,842) children age 6-59 months were screened using upper mid-circumference tape to know their nutritional status.

title.narrative: Percentage of pregnant and breastfeeding mothers with infant and young children 0-23 months old have access to information, counselling and support on the benefits of breastfeeding and complementary feeding

baseline.value: counselling on breast feeding: 152,697 and counselling on complementary feeding: 137,719

target.value: 2017:counselling on breast feeding: 225,708 and target for counselling on complementary feeding: 167,757

actual.value: 2017:During the reporting period, 59 per cent of mothers and caregivers (142,141) of children age 0-23 months received counselling on breastfeeding. Similarly, 51.9 per cent of mothers and caregivers (99,956) of children age 6-23 months received complementary feeding counselling during the reporting peri

title.narrative: % of pregnant women living in EQ affected 14 priority districts covered with recommended dose of IFA and de-worming medicine

baseline.value: pregnant women to who were covered with IFA and deworming: 173,998

actual.value: 2017:Around 19 per cent (53,345) pregnant and lactating women received IFA tablets through the programme during the reporting period.
